title: Wage inequality within and across firms: The role of market forces, government and firm policies
descriptions:
The proposed project, "Wage inequality within and across firms: The role of market forces, government and firm policies," aims to address the increasing wage disparities observed over the past decades in industrialized countries, with a specific focus on gender gaps. The project will draw on data from German social security records, survey data, and administrative data spanning four decades to analyze the effects of market forces, government policies, and firm policies on wage distribution.

Three distinct projects within the proposal will investigate different aspects of wage inequality. Project A will examine the impact of market forces such as product market competition and technological change on wage differentials. Project B will analyze the effects of government policies, including minimum wage introduction and business tax rate changes, on wage inequality. Project C will focus on firm policies, such as family-friendly policies and flexible working times, and their influence on gender disparities in the workplace.

By studying the factors contributing to wage disparities within and between firms, this project seeks to provide valuable insights into the mechanisms driving wage inequality and inform policy interventions to promote more equitable pay practices. The findings from this research will have implications for understanding mothers' return-to-work decisions, earnings trajectories after childbirth, and strategies to address persistent gender gaps in the labor market.

The grant proposal titled "Wage inequality within and across firms: The role of market forces, government, and firm policies" aims to address the increasing wage disparity observed over the past decades in industrialized countries, with a specific focus on gender gaps. By analyzing data from German social security records, survey data, and administrative data spanning four decades, the project will investigate the factors contributing to this inequality.

Three key projects will be conducted as part of this proposal. Project A will explore the impact of market forces such as product market competition and technological change on wage differentials within firms. Project B will analyze the effects of government policies, including minimum wage introduction and changes in business tax rates, on wage inequality. Project C will examine the influence of firm policies, such as family-friendly initiatives and flexible work arrangements, on gender disparities in earnings trajectories.

Overall, this proposal seeks to provide a comprehensive understanding of wage inequality, particularly in relation to gender disparities, by examining the interplay of market forces, government interventions, and firm policies. The research outcomes will contribute valuable insights for policymakers and businesses aiming to address wage disparities and promote greater gender equality in the workforce.

The project "Wage inequality within and across firms: The role of market forces, government and firm policies" aims to address the increasing wage disparity observed over the past decades in industrialised countries, with a specific focus on gender gaps and the impact of factors such as the arrival of children. The research will draw upon a comprehensive dataset spanning four decades, including German social security records, survey data, and administrative data.

Three specific projects will be conducted to analyze the effects of different factors on wage inequality. Project A will focus on market forces such as product market competition and technological change, while Project B will examine the impact of government policies like minimum wage introduction and business tax rate changes. Project C will investigate the influence of firm policies, including family-friendly initiatives and flexible working arrangements, on outcomes such as mothers' return-to-work decisions and earnings trajectories after childbirth.

Overall, this proposal seeks to provide a holistic understanding of wage inequality within and across firms, shedding light on the contributions of market forces, government interventions, and firm practices to this pressing issue, particularly in relation to gender disparities. The findings from this research will have important implications for policy-making and efforts to reduce wage inequality in industrialised economies.
